We're joining together, across the aisle, to ensure that victims of workplace sexual harassment feel safe at their jobs. This culture of sexism and silencing ends now.

Earlier this month, I joined @RepCheri , @RepStefanik, @RepWalterJones, @SenGillibrand, @LindseyGrahamSC and @GretchenCarlson to introduce legislation that would end forced arbitration in cases of sexual harassment. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DRla01fX0AERq0J.jpg

And in cases of sexual harassment, where the power dynamic is stacked against those who come forward, the likelihood of winning a case that goes to trial is much higher than winning one through this secretive process.

Many people don't even know forced arbitration clauses apply to them. Forced arbitration is often slipped into a contract or employee handbook as a condition of employment. Employees often waive their right to take a case to court without truly knowing.

An estimated 60 million Americans are subject to forced arbitration clauses that demand silence and secrecy. These clauses prevent those who have experienced workplace sexual harassment from publicly discussing their stories and getting the justice they deserve.

Proud to see @Microsoft leading the way on eliminating forced arbitration policies. These clauses silence victims, limit opportunity, protect the powerful and break the leadership ladders that we work so hard to build.
